Shortly after he declared victory in the California primary 40 years ago tonight, Robert F.
Kennedy left the luminous ballroom of the Ambassador Hotel in Los Angeles and, as Los Angeles Times columnist Patt Morrison wrote today, walked from America's future into its sorry, bloody past.
The Ambassador closed its doors forever in 1989, and for many years the building that once hosted Winston Churchill, Nikita Khrushchev, Albert Einstein and Richard Nixon was left to wither.
Fights to preserve it failed, and it was demolished in 2006.
But some pieces of its pantry, the actual site of Kennedy's assassination, were preserved, shrink-wrapped on pallets that wait for a special commission to decide where to put it.
In her column, Patt Morrison says something important has already been lost - the actual and authentic place where history stopped, pivoted and took us down a different road.
Do we need to preserve the painful parts of our history, and if so, why?
